awd_titl_txt: Neutrino Physics with Liquid Argon Detectors: Entering the MicroBooNE Era
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all of the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model to date was recently confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN. However, the Standard Model as it currently exists leaves open many questions about the universe, including such fundamental questions as to why the Higgs mass has the value it has and why there is no antimatter in the universe. 

One of the primary areas to search for answers to these and other open questions about the universe, how it came to be and why it is the way it is, is to focus on a study of the properties of neutrinos and to use what we know and can learn about neutrinos as probes of science beyond the Standard Model. Neutrinos are those elementary particles that interact with practically nothing else in the universe. They have no electric charge and were once thought to be massless. Like other elementary particles, they were believed to have an antimatter counterpart, the antineutrino. Moreover, the Standard Model predicted that there were actually three different kinds of neutrinos that were distinguishable through the different interactions that they did undergo whenever there was an interaction. 

But recent measurements have totally changed our picture of neutrinos. We now know that neutrinos do have a mass and because they do, they can actually change from one type to another. Detailed measurements of these changes, along with other current neutrino experiments, form one of the most promising ways to probe for new physics beyond the Standard Model. Such measurements lie at the heart of this project.

There is currently a large interest in experimental particle physics in Liquid Argon Time Projection Chambers (LArTPC) spurred in part by the proposed Long Baseline Neutrino Experiment (LBNE) project at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (FNAL) and in neutrino physics in general. This award supports work which refines LArTPC technology, using a test beam and at the MicroBooNE experiment at FNAL.

LArTPC detector technology is scalable to the very large masses (perhaps 10 kiloTons) needed by next generation neutrino experiments and is capable of recording three-dimensional digital images of particle trajectories. The MicroBooNE will have an active volume of 80 tons of liquid argon and 8256 wires spread over three instrumented wireplanes making up the Time Projection Chamber. MicroBooNE will make a variety of interesting physics measurements, as well as serving as a proving ground for new hardware techniques relevant for future experiments. Among MicroBooNE's primary physics goals is to provide a cross-check of the "low-energy excess" of electron neutrino events previously identified by the MiniBooNE experiment.  There have been recent "hints" that there may be a new type of neutrino, the so-called sterile neutrino. The MicroBoone experiment, with the superior LArTPC, should clarify the situation: either rule out or confirm the sterile neutrino evidence. 

The broader impact of this work will involve graduate students and undergraduates supported by this proposal receiving first-hand experience with High Energy Physics detector development, while also having access to MicroBooNE data that the graduate students will use for their dissertation analyses. The Syracuse group will continue with several outreach efforts as part of this proposal. The group maintains an outreach webpage that includes an "Ask-a-A-Physicist" questionnaire form as well as an active QuarkNet program.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the project supported by NSF Award PHY-1403280 was to develop and utilize the technology of Liquid Argon Time Projection Chambers (LArTPCs) for experimental studies of neutrino interactions.  The technology of LArTPCs appears ideally suited for the study of neutrino interactions, and is being deployed for use in a broad array of experiments that hope to uncover the remaining secrets of neutrinos and what role they have played in the evolution of the universe.  

 
This project enabled members of the Syracuse University neutrino group to participate on a variety of experiments featuring LArTPC detectors (e.g. ArgoNeuT, LArIAT, MicroBooNE, SBND, and DUNE).  On those experiments, group members made important contributions to: data analysis, hardware development, detector commissioning, detector design, and operations.  The intellectual merit of this project centers around the advances in our understanding of the LArTPC technology that group members helped achieve, and also in our activities to extract physics results from these experiments.

On MicroBooNE, the first large LArTPC to be built in the United States, group members have played a variety of important roles.  Soderberg was the editor and primary author of the first MicroBooNE collaboration publication, which described the technical details of the experiment at great length.  Graduate student Jessica Esquivel pursued PhD dissertation work to use software tools from the field of machine learning to better separate signal from background in the Charged-Current inclusive cross-section measurement.  Esquivel successfully defended her PhD describing this work.  Jonathan Asaadi, a postdoctoral researcher in the group at the beginning of the project, was the co-convener of the Astroparticle and Exotica working group on MicroBooNE, helping to shape a number of interesting analyses that MicroBooNE is pursuing.  Postdoctoral researcher Pip Hamilton has served as co-convener of the MicroBooNE Data Quality Management group which is essential in maintaining high-quality data for use in all physics analyses.  Both Hamilton and Asaadi have served as on-call TPC experts, ensuring the stability of the detector during its operations.  

On the LArIAT experiment, which has operated a small LArTPC in the test-beam facility at Fermilab, the Syracuse group was responsible for construction and installation of the TPC.  This work included, in collaboration with collaborators from Boston University and Fermilab, the design and realization of 3 different sets of anode planes with wire pitch of, respectively, 3 mm, 4 mm, and 5 mm.  Soderberg, Asaadi, Hamilton, and graduate student Greg Pulliam, all participated in the wiring of the various anode planes and the subsequent installation on the TPC.  Pulliam is presently using LArIAT data for his dissertation analysis, in which he will measure the cross-section for positively charged pion interactions on argon.  

On the SBND experiment, Soderberg and Hamilton have designed, prototyped, and constructed a custom wiring apparatus that will now be used to install the wires on two SBND Anode Plane Assemblies (APAs).  This is a critical hardware contribution to the eventual SBND detector that will collect the largest statistical sample of neutrino-argon interactions ever to be recorded. On the DUNE experiment, Soderberg has served in various leadership positions in the working group that is focused on DUNE's APAs, helping to specify the design and testing details for these objects.

The broader impacts of this project include the training of young scientists, the dissemination of group activities in conference presentations and journal publications, and outreach efforts to explain particle physics research to the general public.  Group members have been able to disseminate the outcomes of their work at conferences around the globe, facilitated by funding from this project.  Soderberg was active in a local QuarkNet center hosted at Syracuse University, which held multiple events for local high school physics teachers and students.  Group members resident at Fermilab participated in a variety of events to share the excitement of basic particle physics research with the general public.
